readability_reflection: I personally found string concatenation to be more readable. This is likely because C++ is the only high-level language I've learned, and am not particularly familiar with the syntax for string interpolation. For example in C++; a = "Hello ", b = "World", cout << a + b;, then the output would be "Hello World". Same for when came to string interpolation, a = "Hello ", b = "World"  {a}{b}, then the output would be the exact same "Hello World". However, the interpolation syntax was confusing as it seemed like putting a space between {a} {b} would implicitly insert a space, even if " " was not at the end of a = "Hello". Although, at the end of the day it's due to my lack of knowledge and application for string interpolation that leads me to say that string concatenation is more readable.
comprehension_debugging: String concatenation was a bit confusing at first, but I quickly picked up what the syntax doing. I have sufficient experience using and understanding string concatenation, so string concatenation was the only one I struggled with. The only challenge I experienced was determining if a space was implicitly inserted between {a} {b}.
preference_rationale: I would personally choose string concatenation because of my understanding and experience using it in C++. Although this is not a definite choice, if other languages used the same/similar syntax for string concatenation, then that would be my preferred choice.
learning_curve: My familiarity and experience with string concatenation helped significantly with understanding the code examples. With the example for string interpolation, I had to take longer to first understand the syntax and see how it operates.
suggestions_improvement: No suggestions for either string interpolation or concatenation syntax. Although I struggled with string interpolation at first, it appears straightforward and identical in function with string concatenation. However for readability, I don't like using {} as they already serve many other uses in code, and can be confusing when trying to analyze or debug a large file.
